HadesR package¶

Submodules¶

HadesR.hades_input module¶

class HadesR.hades_input.hades_input(data_path, event_file, station_file, sta_select)¶

Bases: object

This class prepares earthquake data (formatted correctly) for the hades_location class.

Parameters:

  • data_path (string) – Path to the data (event, stations).

  • event_file (string) – Filename of the event file (.dat).

  • station_file (string) – Filename of the station file (.txt)

  • sta_select (list) – A selection of two stations if multiple stations are available in the event file.

distance_calculation(Vp, Vs, sta, dist=None)¶

This method calculates the inter-event distance matrix for the entire dataset. Input: It requires the P and S wave velocities and the station name. For single station mode sta needs to be string with the name of the station “STANAME”, for multistation sta needs to be a list with the stations [“STANAME_1”, “STANAME_2”, … ,”STANAME_N”].

relative_frame(Vp, Vs, sta, y_ref=-1, z_ref=-1, fixed_depth=0)¶

Constructs a relative reference frame on basis of your reference events.

Params¶

Vpfloat

P-wave velocity (homogeneous) in [m/s]

Vsfloat

S-wave velocity (homogeneous) in [m/s]

stalist

Stations list

y_refint

Y-reference initial sign, -1 or 1 (flips over y-axis)

z_refint

Z-reference initial sign, -1 or 1 (flips over z-axis)

fixed_depthfloat

The ‘depth’ between your events in m

HadesR.hades_location module¶

class HadesR.hades_location.hades_location(input_obj, output_path, output_frame, verbose=False)¶

Bases: object

This class takes input objects from hades_input.py to locate events with respect to other events (relative location), after which an absolute location is found using 1 (relative mode) or more (< 4, absolute) master events.

Parameters:

  • input_obj (hades.input.Struct) – Input object from hades_input.py.

  • output_path (string) – Output filename or path.

  • output_frame (string) – Output reference frame, choices are ‘cart’ or ‘latlon’. Cartesian means with the origin at 0 and all in meters.

References

See [Grigoli et al. 2021] for further details.

location(filename, mode, plot)¶

Decision module that dictates what hades_location will do according to the mode of operation (‘rel’ or ‘abs). Relative relocation means relative to one master event, absolute means within the reference coordinate system of the minimum of four master events.

Parameters:

  • filename (string) – Output file filename or path.

  • mode (string) – Absolute (‘abs’) or relative mode (‘rel’).

  • plot (bool) – Plot the rectilinearity and location results.

Return type:

None

HadesR.hades_rotation module¶

class HadesR.hades_rotation.Cluster(cluster, axis, stations, bary, subcluster, vs, vp, dtps_org, cluster_true)¶

Bases: object

This class can do 3D rotation optimization on a cluster of points (or earthquakes). What’s different from rotations_class? That is that here I try to include a list of stations instead of just two.

BASINHOPPING_ITERATIONS = 350¶
BASINHOPPING_TEMPERATURE = 120¶
DEGREES_FULL_RANGE = (0, 359)¶
DIFF_EVOLUTION_MAXITER = 1000¶
DUAL_ANNEALING_INITIAL_TEMP = 50000¶
DUAL_ANNEALING_MAXITER = 10000¶
DUAL_ANNEALING_RESTART_TEMP_RATIO = 2e-06¶
DUAL_ANNEALING_VISIT = 2.9¶
GRID_POINTS_PER_DIMENSION = 72¶
NUM_WORKERS = 4¶
a_quat(theta)¶

Quaternions for rotation of theta radians around ax0 axis

Parameters:

theta (scalar) – Rotation angle in radians

Returns:

r_a

Return type:

quaternion for the rotation

apply_rotations(cluster, rotations)¶

Applies rotations (quaternion-wise) to the cluster cluster: your cluster of points rotations: given in quaternions around the 3 axes

apply_rotations_spatial(cluster, rotations)¶

Applies rotations (quaternion-wise) to the cluster cluster: your cluster of points rotations: given in quaternions around the 3 axes

b_quat(theta)¶

Quaternions for rotation of theta radians around ax1 axis

Parameters:

theta (scalar) – Rotation angle in radians

Returns:

r_a

Return type:

quaternion for the rotation

c_quat(theta)¶

Quaternions for rotation of theta radians around ax2 axis :param theta: Rotation angle in radians :type theta: scalar

Returns:

r_a

Return type:

quaternion for the rotation

correl_mismatch(dtps_org, dtps_rot)¶

Negative correlation between the two clusters, flattened to 1D

Parameters:

  • dtps_org (array) – The original cluster

  • dtps_rot (array) – The rotated cluster

Returns:

correl – The negative correlation value

Return type:

float

cost_function(rotations)¶

Computes cost function of the rotation problem. Options are different mismatch metrics, e.g., rms_mismach, l1_norm or correl_mismatch.

Parameters:

rotations (array) – The rotations in degrees

Returns:

cost – The cost value

Return type:

float

invert_rotations_spatial(cluster, rotations)¶

Inverts the rotations (quaternion-wise) to the cluster

cluster: your cluster of points rotations: given in quaternions around the 3 axes

Returns:

cF – The inverted cluster

Return type:

array

l1_mismatch(dtps_org, dtps_rot)¶

L1 norm mismatch between the two clusters in traveltime

optimize_rotations(prior, method, optall)¶

the optimizer using different scipy optimizers.

prior: an initial guess of the degree amount (standard: [0, 0, 0]) method: choose between powell, cg (conjugate gradient), bfgs (mostly the most efficient) optall: Bool, use all events or only master events

Returns:

thetas

Return type:

the optimized angles in degrees

pca_theta_calculation(evtsps, c_try, plot=False)¶

Computes the rectilinearity of the cluster, which is a measure of how well the cluster is aligned with the PCA axes. The rectilinearity is computed by taking the ratio of the largest to the smallest eigenvalue of the covariance matrix of the cluster.

Parameters:

  • evtsps (array) – The traveltime differences of the cluster

  • c_try (array) – The cluster to be tested

  • plot (bool, optional) – If True, a plot of the PCA is shown, by default False

Returns:

rect – The rectilinearity of the cluster

Return type:

float

rms_mismatch(dtps_org, dtps_rot)¶

RMS mismatch value between the two clusters in traveltime

Parameters:

  • dtps_org (array) – The original cluster

  • dtps_rot (array) – The rotated cluster

Returns:

rms – The RMS mismatch value

Return type:

float

rms_mismatch_abs(cluster_rot)¶

RMS mismatch value between the two clusters in absolute sense (not demeaned)

Parameters:

cluster_rot (array) – The rotated cluster

Returns:

rms – The RMS mismatch value

Return type:

float

HadesR.hades_utils module¶

HadesR.hades_utils.distance_calculation(cluster, station)¶

Calculates the distances between cluster and station.

Params¶

clusternumpy.ndarray

Array with cluster coords of N events [N,3]

stationnumpy.ndarray

Array with station coords [1,3]

returns:

distances – Array with distances of N events [1,N]

rtype:

numpy.ndarray

HadesR.hades_utils.find_element_in_list(element, list_element)¶

Finds element in list.

HadesR.hades_utils.flip_sign(cluster, x, y, z, b)¶
HadesR.hades_utils.inter_iter_error(cluster1, cluster2)¶

Calculates the distance error between two consecutive point clouds cluster1 and cluster 2

Params¶

cluster1numpy.ndarray

3D Array with cluster coords of N events [N,3]

cluster2numpy.ndarray

3D Array with cluster coords of N events [N,3]

returns:

  • distances (numpy.ndarray) – 3D Array with distances of N events [N,3]

  • stdev (numpy.ndarray) – 1D Array with standard deviations of N events [N,1]

HadesR.hades_utils.make_datfile(path, filename, ref_idx, ref_coords, origin, station_names, p_times, s_times)¶

Makes HADES event input file.

You can list all recording stations and only use a subset later. The file structure: ORIGIN;lat;lon;depth; #(R)eventno;eventtime;lat;lon;depth; station_name;p_time;s_time; … #(R)evtno;….

Parameters:

  • path (string) – String with the path to deposit the event.dat file

  • filename (string) – File name of your event input file

  • ref_idx (list or numpy.ndarray) – List of array of indexes of your master events (minimum 4)

  • ref_coords (numpy.ndarray) – Array [M, 3] of M master events with their lat, lon depth coordinates. If you only have one master event, use 0,0,0 as coordinates for the other events.

  • origin (numpy.ndarray or list) – Origin coordinates of the cluster. Can be the literal barycentre or the coordinates of the first master event (default).

  • station_names (list) – List of station names. Must be present in the station file as well.

  • p_times (list) – List of p-pick timestrings in the format %Y/%d/%m %H:%M:%S.%f

  • s_times (list) – List of s-pick timestrings in the format %Y/%d/%m %H:%M:%S.%f

HadesR.hades_utils.make_statfile(path, filename, station_names, station_coordinates)¶

Makes a HADES station input file.

You can list all recording stations and only use a subset later. With structure: station_name lat lon depth[km]

Parameters:

  • path (string) – String with the path to deposit the station.txt file

  • filename (str) – Filename of the station file

  • station_names (list) – List of station names. If stations don’t have specific names, make a logical naming system such as [‘STA001’, … ‘STA0015’]

  • station_coordinates (numpy.ndarray) – Numpy array [N, 3] of station [latitude, longitude, depth]

HadesR.hades_utils.plot_multirun()¶
HadesR.hades_utils.plot_tstp()¶
HadesR.hades_utils.sortout(orig, refarray)¶

HadesR.rotations_utils module¶

HadesR.rotations_utils.apply_rotations_spatial(cluster, rotations)¶
HadesR.rotations_utils.compute_distance(x_c, x_r, frame)¶

Computes the 3D Euclidean distance between points x_c: location of the cluster

if spherical coords, make sure to frame it as lat, lon, depth

x_r: location of the receiver frame: Bool, for Cartesian set False, for Spherical (WGS84) set True

HadesR.rotations_utils.compute_traveltime(cluster, stat, vp, vs, frame, noise=0)¶

computes the traveltimes between cluster points and station coordinates cluster : your earthquake cluster (or any point cluster) station : the station you would like to compute the traveltimes for vp, vs : p- and s-wave velocities in [m/s] frame : Bool, set to either spherical (latlon) – True, or False for UTM noise : ONLY USE FOR TESTING. Percentage of noise you’d like to add (default is zero)

HadesR.rotations_utils.define_axis_vectors(sta, bary)¶

Method that defines the three axes of rotation v0, v1, v2 that are comprised of: - the vertical axis from the barycentre upwards - the projected axis on the horizontal between a station and the barycentre - the axis normal to the plane spanned between the two previous axes

HadesR.rotations_utils.demean_traveltimes(tt)¶

Removes the mean from the computed traveltimes. Serves to remove part of the error that is contained in the difference between observed wavefields (traveled through a complex medium) and the simple homogeneous model with straight euclidean distance in the trial data. tt: traveltime array

HadesR.rotations_utils.distance_error(cl1, cl2)¶

compute the distance error if there is a ‘correct’ cluster present to compare with.

HadesR.rotations_utils.pca_theta_calculation(cluster_comp, evtsps, stations, plot)¶
